Abebe Bikila.passage: Abebe Bikila (born 26 March 1932) is a former Ethiopian long-distance runner. He is one of the most celebrated long distance runners in the history of athletics. He is a four-time winner of the Olympic marathon, and is one of only two men in history to win the Olympic marathon twice in a row, having accomplished this feat at the 1960 Rome and the 1964 Tokyo Games, and he is also the only man to win the Olympic marathon three times, having achieved this at the 1964 Tokyo and the 1968 Mexico City Games. Bikila was a member of the Ethiopian team that won the gold medal in the 10,000 m at the 1960 Rome Olympics, and also a member of the team that won the silver medal in the marathon at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics. He won the Boston Marathon in 1965, and set a course record of 2:15:16. Bikila was born in Bonga, a town in the Oromia Region in Ethiopia. He began his career as a steeplechase runner, but later switched to longer distance running. He was a three-time winner of the Rome-Berlin race, and was the first man to run a marathon in under 2 hours and 15 minutes. He also won the Paris Marathon in 1969. Bikila is the only man to win the Boston and the Boston Public Garden Marathons, having accomplished this in 1965.

Bobby Moore.passage:
The following is a detailed passage about Bobby Moore from wikipedia:

Bobby Moore (born Robert Anthony Moore; 17 January 1946) is an English former footballer who played as a defender for West Ham United. He was the captain of the club and is widely regarded as one of the greatest defenders of all time. He was a member of the West Ham teams that won the 1966 and 1970 FA Cups. He played 442 times for West Ham in all competitions, and was named Hammer of the Year on two occasions. He was inducted into the English Football Hall of Fame in 2002, and was voted England's Footballer of the 20th Century by the public. Moore began his career at West Ham in 1963, and was a member of the team that won promotion to the First Division in 1966. He was a key member of the West Ham side which won two successive FA Cup finals in 1970 and 1974, captaining the team in both finals. He played for West Ham until 1976, and retired in 1978. Moore made his international debut for England in 1965. He went on to captain the team on 55 occasions, and played in three World Cups, in 1966, 1974 and 1978. He was named as the Footballer of the Year by the Football Writers' Association in 1971, and as England's Footballer of the 20th Century by the public in 1999.

Paavo Nurmi.passage: Paavo Nurmi (2 May 1897 – 20 March 1973) was a Finnish runner who specialized in long-distance running, and was the most successful long-distance athlete of the early 20th century. He won nine Olympic medals, including six gold medals, and set world record in the 5 km, 10 km, and 20 km races. Nurmi was also an accomplished cross-country skier and a world-class gymnast. He won five cross-country skiing events at the 1920 and 1924 Winter Olympics, and was a member of the Finnish teams that won the team cross-country skiing event at the 1926 and 1932 Winter Olympics. He also competed in artistic gymnastics at the 1924 Summer Olympics. Nurmi was born in Kontiolahti, a small village in the municipality of Kauhajoki, in the Grand Duchy of Finland, then part of the Russian Empire. He was the second of four children of Matti and Hilja (née Kettunen) Nurmi. His father was a shoemaker and his mother was a farmer's daughter. His parents had eight children, of whom Nurmi was the second-oldest. Nurmi's talent for sports emerged early, and at age 12 he won a local 10 km cross-country skiing race. In 1913, he won his first long-distance running event, a 20 km race in Turku.

Phelps was born in York, Pennsylvania. His father, Bob, is a former minor league baseball player and coach, and his mother, Debbie, is a former competitive swimmer and high school swimming coach. His maternal grandfather was Jewish, and his maternal great-grandfather was a Lithuanian Jew. Phelps was raised in Salisbury, Maryland. He began swimming at the age of four and took up the butterfly and backstroke at eight, and was a member of the Cal Ripken Collegiate Club. In 2001, Phelps won the 200- and 400-meter individual medley at both the Junior World Championships and the World Short Course Championships. Shawn Kemp.passage: Shawn Kemp (born March 26, 1968) is an American retired professional basketball player. He was a two-time NBA All-Star, and a three-time All-Star in Europe, and was selected to the NBA All-Rookie First Team in 1991–92. He is currently the assistant coach for the Seattle SuperSonics. Kemp attended the University of Kansas, where he led the Jayhawks to the 1988 NCAA Championship Game and was named the Most Outstanding Player of the Final Four. He is the only Kansas player to be named an All-American four times. Kemp was selected by the Seattle SuperSonics with the first overall pick in the 1991 NBA draft. He played for the Sonics for nine seasons, and was selected to three All-Star games. He played for the Vancouver/Memphis Grizzlies, the Cleveland Cavaliers, the Portland Trail Blazers, the Milwaukee Bucks, and the Orlando Magic before announcing his retirement from the NBA on February 20, 2004. Kemp is the only player in NBA history to record a quadruple double while playing in a regular season game. He is also one of two players in NBA history to have recorded at least 20 points, 10 rebounds, 10 assists, and 10 steals in a single game, and the only player to have done so on three separate occasions.

the Boston Marathon.passage: The Boston Marathon is the world’s oldest annual marathon. It was first run on April 19, 1897, and was held annually until 1983. Ethiopia.passage: Ethiopia (i/ˌɛfˈriːθiə/; Arabic: عوبيتي‎ ‎ (ʔʊbwˈitī); Amharic: አቡባኤልት (ʔɐ̃wˈtʃiːnɛ)) is a country located in the Horn of Africa, bordered by Eritrea to the north, Sudan to the south, Kenya to the west, and Djibouti and Somalia to the east. It is the second-most populous landlocked country after Kazakhstan, and has the 19th largest economy by nominal GDP and the 38th largest economy by PPP in the world. Ethiopia is the oldest independent nation in Africa. It became a kingdom in the fourth century and thereafter a powerful empire, controlling much of the African continent. It was the only African country to have a continuous empire from 3000 BC until 1100 AD. The Ethiopian Empire was the first in history to have a written script, the Ge'ez script, and its church, the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, is the oldest Christian Church in Africa. Ethiopia is the homeland of the Solomonic dynasty and the Axumite Empire, as well as the birthplace of the Zagwe dynasty.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, the oldest Christian Church in Africa.

York.passage: York (UK: /ˈjɔːk/; US: /ˈdʒɔːk/), officially the City of York, is the largest and most populated city in the North Island of the British overseas territory of England (the other two main islands are the Isle of Wight and the Anglesey). Pennsylvania.passage: Pennsylvania (Pennsylvania German: [ˈpɛnˌtɔːlɐˌwɪd͡ʒə]; Pennsylvania Dutch: [ˈpɛnˌtɔːlɐ ˈduːʒə]; Pennsylvania-German: [ˈpɛnˌtɔːlɐ ˈduːʒə]; Lenape: [ˈlɛnˌpɛː]) is the second-most populous and the fifth-most extensive U.S. state. Located in the Mid-Atlantic and Great Appalachian regions, Pennsylvania is the 33rd largest and the 9th most densely populated of the 50 United States. The state is bordered by New York to the north, New Jersey and Delaware to the southeast, Maryland to the south, and Ohio and West Virginia to the southwest. The Appalachian Mountains run through the state, creating numerous scenic valleys, lowlands, and peaks. The state has a maritime and inland delta along the coast of the Atlantic Ocean, a wide valley known as the Great Appalachian Valley, and the vast Allegheny Plateau.

Massachusetts.passage: The Massachusetts state legislature is the state legislature of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in the United States. It is a bicameral body, with a lower house (the House of Representatives) and an upper house (the Senate). The House of Representatives consists of 150 members, elected to two-year terms, and the Senate has 40 members, elected to four-year terms. The Massachusetts state government is based in Boston. Men of Vizion.passage: Men of Vizion is a science fiction novel by American writer Robert Silverberg. It was published in 1980 by Gnome Press in an edition of 3,000 copies, of which 300 were hand-numbered and signed by the author. R&B.passage: Rhythm and blues (R&B), also known simply as blues, is a genre of African-American popular music that originated in the 1940s. It combines elements of blues, gospel music, and jazz. R&B is noted for its use of vocal harmonies, piano, organ, guitar, electric bass, drums and percussion, as well as a horn section (trumpet, saxophone, and trombone). The style often features a strong back beat of the drums and bass.

the Seattle SuperSonics.passage: The Seattle SuperSonics are an American professional basketball team based in Seattle.
